claim: The knights in the Medieval Times show are authentic knights.

supporting.text: The knights in the Medieval Times show are performers, not historical knights, as their primary role is entertainment rather than military service.

attacks.text: The knights in the Medieval Times show are performers, not historical knights, as their primary role is entertainment rather than military service.
While they are performers, the knights in the show undergo rigorous training in historical combat techniques, making their portrayal authentic in terms of skills.
Historical combat techniques in the show are often stylized or simplified for entertainment, deviating from actual medieval warfare practices.
The armor and weapons used in the show are replicas of historical designs, adding to the authenticity of their portrayal.
The replicas are often made with modern materials and techniques, which differ significantly from the original craftsmanship and functionality.

supporting.text: Authentic medieval knights were part of a feudal system and swore allegiance to a lord or monarch, which is not the case for the performers in the show.

attacks.text: Authentic medieval knights were part of a feudal system and swore allegiance to a lord or monarch, which is not the case for the performers in the show.
The performers in the Medieval Times show are trained to replicate the combat techniques and chivalric codes of medieval knights, making them authentic in a modern entertainment context.
Replication of combat techniques and chivalric codes does not equate to authenticity, as authenticity requires historical context and feudal obligations.
Modern interpretations of historical roles can still be considered authentic if they adhere to the spirit and values of the original, even if the feudal context is absent.

supporting.text: The armor and weapons used in the Medieval Times show are designed for theatrical combat, not historical accuracy or battlefield functionality.

attacks.text: The armor and weapons used in the Medieval Times show are designed for theatrical combat, not historical accuracy or battlefield functionality.
Some armor and weapons in the show are replicas of historical artifacts, demonstrating attention to historical detail.
Even if replicas exist, their materials and construction methods are often modernized for safety and cost, compromising authenticity.
Theatrical combat techniques are derived from historical martial arts manuals, preserving some authenticity in movement.
Derived techniques are heavily stylized for entertainment, diverging significantly from actual medieval combat practices.

supporting.text: Historical knights underwent rigorous training and participated in real battles, while the performers in the show are trained in choreographed routines.

attacks.text: Historical knights underwent rigorous training and participated in real battles, while the performers in the show are trained in choreographed routines.
The Medieval Times show aims to entertain rather than replicate history exactly, so authenticity in the strictest sense is not the goal.
Even if the show is for entertainment, it still misleads audiences by presenting performers as authentic knights without proper historical context.
Many performers in the show undergo extensive training in horseback riding and combat techniques, which are similar to skills historical knights would have had.
While the skills may overlap, the context and purpose of the training are fundamentally different, as historical knights trained for warfare, not performance.

supporting.text: The Medieval Times show is a modern creation, first established in 1977, and thus cannot feature authentic medieval knights.

attacks.text: The Medieval Times show is a modern creation, first established in 1977, and thus cannot feature authentic medieval knights.
Authentic medieval knights no longer exist, so the show's performers cannot be authentic regardless of the show's age.
The show may still accurately represent medieval knightly traditions and combat techniques, even if the performers are not literally medieval knights.
Historical accuracy in performance does not equate to authenticity, as authenticity requires genuine historical context and lineage.
